facts.text: Appellants conducting prize competitions in State of Mysore since August 1948 with permission of erstwhile State of Mysore Government.
Mysore Lotteries and Prize Competitions Control and Tax Act, 1951 (Act 27 of 1951) passed by Mysore Legislature, came into force June 21, 1951; Rules effective February 1, 1952.
Bombay Lotteries and Prize Competitions Control and Tax Act, 1948 amended by Bombay Act 30 of 1952 in November 1952.
Petitions under Art. 226 filed in Bombay High Court in December 1952 and January 1953 challenging Bombay Act.
Bombay High Court on January 12, 1955 held Bombay Amendment Act unconstitutional, taxes hit by Art. 301.
States of Andhra, Bombay, Madras, U.P., Hyderabad, Madhya Bharat, Pepsu, Saurashtra passed resolutions under Art. 252(1) authorizing Parliament to legislate on prize competitions.
Parliament passed Prize Competitions Act, 1955 (Act 42 of 1955), assented October 22, 1955, effective April 1, 1956.
Mysore Legislature passed resolution adopting Central Act on February 24, 1956 (Assembly Feb 23, Council Feb 21).
Appellants filed Art. 32 petition in Supreme Court on April 7, 1956 challenging Central Act; dismissed, reported as R.M.D.C. Chamarbaugwala v. Union of India.
Stay of Central Act granted to appellants on April 16, 1956 pending Art. 32 petition.
Supreme Court judgment in Art. 32 petition on April 9, 1957.
Supreme Court allowed appeal against Bombay High Court judgment, reported as State of Bombay v. R.M.D. Chamarbaugwala.
Mysore Lotteries Prize Competitions Control and Tax Amendment Ordinance, 1957 (Ord. 6 of 1957) issued August 31, 1957.

Ordinance enacted as Mysore Act 26 of 1957 on September 28, 1957; amended Mysore Act 1951: adopted Central Act definition, omitted ss. 8,9 retrospectively from April 1, 1956, amended s.12(1)(b), proviso to s.15 covering competitions March 31,1956 to August 31,1957.
Appellants called to file returns September 10, 1957; extension to 15 days granted; filed under protest showing gross collections Rs. 26,47,147-5-9; provisional tax demand Rs. 3,30,893-7-0.
Proceedings under s.6(1) Revenue Recovery Act, 1890; properties attached, one sold, proceeds deposited.
Appellants filed Art. 226 petition in Mysore High Court challenging Mysore amending Act; dismissed November 20, 1958.
Appeal to Supreme Court with certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) confined to Art. 252 interpretation.

legal_issues.text: Whether Mysore Legislature by adopting Central Act surrendered power to legislate on prize competitions including taxation.
Whether amended Mysore Act violates Art. 252(2) by indirectly amending Central Act via penalties/tax.
Whether Mysore Legislature could amend Act repealed by Central Act.
Whether amended Mysore Act repugnant to Central Act, void under Art. 254(1).
Whether Mysore Act is colourable legislation, tax imposed for control not revenue.
Legality of tax imposition and recovery proceedings.

petitioner_arguments.text: Mysore Legislature no longer competent to pass law on prize competitions as whole power including taxation surrendered to Parliament via Art. 252(1) resolutions.
Amended Mysore Act violates Art. 252(2) by indirectly amending Central Act, adding control via monetary penalties.
Mysore Legislature could not amend Act which stood repealed by Central Act.
Amended Mysore Act repugnant to Central Act, void under Art. 254(1).
Tax is colourable legislation for control of prize competitions.
Assessment provisional not contemplated; no fresh notification post-amendment; tax not due at recovery time.

respondent_arguments.text: Art. 252(1) complete code; Art. 254 inapplicable as no Concurrent List repugnancy.
Inconsistency only affects licensing portions; amendment omits repugnant words retrospectively.
Assessment final, not provisional; notification valid; demand properly made.

court_reasoning.text: Resolutions under Art. 252(1) surrendered control/regulation (Entry 34 List II) but not separate taxation power (Entry 62 List II).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Entries separate; control/regulation does not include tax.

court_reasoning.text: No violation of Art. 252(2); tax under separate entry, not amendment of Central Act or new control method.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tax valid exercise of Entry 62 power.

court_reasoning.text: No repeal of Mysore Act by Central Act; amendment valid retrospectively.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Central Act covers control, not tax.

court_reasoning.text: No repugnancy under Art. 254(1); repugnant licensing words omitted retrospectively; doctrine of eclipse applies.
Not colourable; motives irrelevant if competent; tax for revenue under Entry 62.
Assessment final based on accepted returns; no fresh notification needed; demand proper, no payment made.

holdings.text: Resolutions did not surrender taxation power; Entries 34 and 62 distinct.
Amended Mysore Act not violative of Art. 252(2), not colourable, no indirect amendment.
Mysore Legislature competent to amend its Act retrospectively.
No repugnancy post-amendment; Art. 254(1) not rendering tax void.
Tax valid under Entry 62; not colourable legislation.

key_quotes.text: "By passing the resolutions as to control and regulation the power to tax had not been surrendered to Parliament."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The entries in the Lists have to be read in accordance with the words employed and it will be wholly unjustified in forcing into them a meaning which they cannot reasonably bear."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "If the legislature is competent to pass a particular law, the motives which impelled it to act are really irrelevant."
key_quotes.speaker: court
